attributes.Title: ST-Egyptian Arabic I
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197K
UMass Amherst
Egyptian Arabic I is offered in a special independent study format through the Five College Center for the Study of World Languages. The course develops speaking and listening skills in Egyptian Arabic. The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions with a native speaker and a final evaluation by an outside evaluator. In order to enroll in this course, students must have completed the equivalent of one year of elementary Modern Standard Arabic in a course with a speaking component in Modern Standard Arabic or a dialect. Students studying Egyptian Arabic develop skills needed for study abroad in Egypt and to support course work in Middle Eastern, African and International Studies.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.
67196

attributes.Title: Ideas That Change the World
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201
UMass Amherst
In this seminar, students will examine texts and works of art that have profoundly shaped the world we live in. The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
16389

attributes.Title: ST-Egyptian Arabic II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197BF
UMass Amherst
Egyptian Arabic II is offered in a special independent study format through the Five College Center for the Study of World Languages. The course develops speaking and listening skills in colloquial Egyptian Arabic. The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions with a native speaker and a final evaluation by an outside evaluator. In order to enroll in this course, students must have completed Egyptian Arabic I or the equivalent. Students whose first-year classroom Arabic course included significant conversation practice in Egyptian may be able to place into Egyptian II. Students studying Egyptian Arabic develop skills needed for study abroad in Egypt and to support course work in Middle Eastern, African and International Studies.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.
67195

attributes.Title: Intrmd Four-Skilled Arabic II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Arabic
202
UMass Amherst
Students in this course will continue perfecting thier knowledge of Arabic focusing on the four skills: speaking, listening, reading, and writing.  Students should expect text assignments as well as work with DVDs, audio and websites.  Exercises include writing, social interatctions, role plays, and the interplay of language and culture.
PreReq: ARABIC 201  Pre-Requisites or Consent of Instructor
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63068
Requisite: PreReq: ARABIC 201  Pre-Requisites or Consent of Instructor

attributes.Title: Elementary Arabic II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Arabic
146
UMass Amherst
Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic, also known as classical Arabic. This two-semester course covers the basics in first-year Arabic; study of the alphabet, sounds, and writing style, and development of basic grammatical structures and communication skills. Students read and write short passages on various real-life situations. Prerequisite: ARABIC 126.
Pre Req: ARABIC 126  Class meets one extra hour weekly by arrangement.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63056
Requisite: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic, also known as classical Arabic. This two-semester course covers the basics in first-year Arabic; study of the alphabet, sounds, and writing style, and development of basic grammatical structures and communication skills. Students read and write short passages on various real-life situations. Prerequisite: ARABIC 126.

attributes.Title: Elemntr Four-Skilled Arabic II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Arabic
102
UMass Amherst
This course is a continuation of Arabic 101.  Students will complete the study of the Elementary Arabic book sequence. Emphasis will be on the development of all language skills using a communicative-oriented, proficiency-based approach. By the end of the academic year, students will acquire vocabulary and usage for everyday interactions as well as skills that will allow them to communicate in a variety of situations. In addition to the traditional textbook exercises, students will write short essays and participate in role plays, discussions, and conversations throughout the semester.
PreReq: ARABIC 101/LLC 197FA
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63067

attributes.Title: S-I Levantine Arabic I
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197XX
UMass Amherst
Levantine Arabic I is offered in a special independent study format through the Five College Center for the Study of World Languages. The course develops speaking and listening skills in colloquial Jordanian, Lebanese, Palestinian, and Syrian Arabic. The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions with a native speaker and a final evaluation by an outside evaluator. In order to enroll in this course, students must have completed the equivalent of one year of elementary Modern Standard Arabic in a course with a speaking component in Modern Standard Arabic or a dialect. Students studying Levantine Arabic develop skills needed for study abroad in Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, Syria or the West Bank and to support course work in Middle Eastern and International Studies.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.
67174

The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions with a native speaker and a final evaluation by an outside evaluator. In order to enroll in this course, students must have completed Levantine Arabic II or the equivalent. Students studying Levantine Arabic develop skills needed for study abroad in Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, Syria or the West Bank and to support course work in Middle Eastern and International Studies.

attributes.Title: Elemntr Four-Skilled Arabic I
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Arabic
101
UMass Amherst
This first semester of a year-long course introduces the basics of Modern Standard Arabic, also known as Classical Arabic. It begins with a coverage of the alphabet, vocabulary for everyday use, and essential communicative skills relating to real-life and task-oriented situations (queries about personal well-being, family, work, and telling the time). Students will concentrate on speaking and listening skills, as well as on learning the various forms of regular verbs, and on how to use an Arabic dictionary.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
33081

attributes.Title: Intermediate Arabic II
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Arabic
246
UMass Amherst
The second year of Modern Standard Arabic; expanding the grammatical and syntactical structures necessary for reading basic forms of literary Arabic. Samples include: newspaper excerpts, short stories, descriptive narratives. Emphasis also placed on writing short essays and developing oral skills, using a broader range of regular and irregular verbs. At the end of the second semester, students examine a range of Arabic news broadcasts. Prerequisite: ARABIC 146.
Pre Req: ARABIC 226
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63052
Requisite: The second year of Modern Standard Arabic; expanding the grammatical and syntactical structures necessary for reading basic forms of literary Arabic. Samples include: newspaper excerpts, short stories, descriptive narratives. Emphasis also placed on writing short essays and developing oral skills, using a broader range of regular and irregular verbs. At the end of the second semester, students examine a range of Arabic news broadcasts. Prerequisite: ARABIC 146.

attributes.Title: S-I Moroccan Arabic I
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197BX
UMass Amherst
This course develops speaking and listening skills in colloquial Moroccan Arabic. The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions with a native speaker and a final evaluation by an outside evaluator. In order to enroll in this course, students must have completed two semesters of Modern Standard Arabic at the 100-level or the equivalent. This course is appropriate for students who have had at least one year of Modern Standard Arabic that included a significant speaking component in either MSA or a dialect. The focus is on practical everyday conversation and listening comprehension. Students studying Moroccan Arabic develop skills needed for study abroad in Morocco and to support course work in Middle Eastern and International Studies.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.

attributes.Title: ST-Levantine Arabic VI
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Five Coll Ctr: World Languages
197LS
UMass Amherst
Levantine Arabic VI is offered in a special independent study format through the Five College Center for the Study of World Languages. The course develops speaking and listening skills in colloquial Jordanian, Lebanese, Palestinian, and Syrian Arabic. The independent study format includes small group conversation sessions with a native speaker and a final evaluation by an outside evaluator. In order to enroll in this course, students must have completed Levantine Arabic V or the equivalent and be comfortable with advanced level speaking and listening skills. Enrolled students participate in choosing discussion topics.
Students must apply to add this course at www.fivecolleges.edu/fclang.
For info email: fclang@fivecolleges.edu or call 413-542-5264.
Prerequisite: Levantine I, II, III, IV, & V or equivalent
